title: Who May Dwell with God
shortSummary: Psalm 15 is a concise yet profound psalm by David that outlines the moral and spiritual qualities required to dwell in God's presence. It emphasizes integrity, righteousness, truthfulness, and justice as marks of those who are welcome in the holy sanctuary. This chapter serves as a timeless guide for holy living and fellowship with God.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - Reign of King David

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The author of the psalm, King of Israel, who poses the question about who may dwell in God's holy presence.

keyCharacters.name: The Righteous Person
keyCharacters.description: The individual described in the psalm who meets God's standards of holiness and integrity.

definitions.definition: The portable sanctuary where God's presence dwelt among the Israelites before the temple was built.
The practice of charging interest on loans, which was forbidden among God's people to protect the poor and innocent.
Speaking maliciously or slanderously about someone behind their back.
A cause of disgrace or shame; in this context, refusing to accept slander or false accusations against a neighbor.

outline.heading: The Question of Fellowship with God
outline.description: David opens with a solemn inquiry about who is worthy to dwell in God's sacred presence, setting the theme for the psalm.

outline.heading: The Character of the Upright
outline.description: Describes the righteous person as one who walks uprightly, does what is right, and speaks truth from the heart.

outline.heading: Integrity in Speech and Conduct
outline.description: Highlights the importance of refraining from slander, doing no harm to neighbors, and not accepting false accusations.

outline.heading: Respect for the Godly and Faithfulness
outline.description: The righteous person despises evil, honors those who fear the LORD, and keeps promises even when it is to their own detriment.

outline.heading: Justice in Financial and Legal Matters
outline.description: Prohibits charging interest or accepting bribes against the innocent, concluding that those who live this way will remain unshaken.

application: Examine your daily conduct to ensure it aligns with walking uprightly and practicing righteousness in all areas of life.
Guard your speech by avoiding gossip, slander, and harmful words against others, reflecting Christlike love and truth.
Commit to faithfulness in your promises and integrity in financial dealings, trusting God to uphold you.
Honor and respect those who fear the Lord, fostering a community grounded in reverence for God.

keyVerses.text: He that walketh uprightly, and worketh righteousness, and speaketh the truth in his heart.
keyVerses.significance: This verse succinctly captures the essential qualities of a person who is fit to dwell with God.

keyVerses.text: In whose eyes a vile person is contemned; but he honoureth them that fear the LORD. He that sweareth to his own hurt, and changeth not.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the importance of honoring God-fearing people and maintaining faithfulness even at personal cost.

keyVerses.text: He that putteth not out his money to usury, nor taketh reward against the innocent. He that doeth these things shall never be moved.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes justice and integrity in financial and legal matters as foundational to stability before God.
